node.title: Ministers blame each other for 'orchestrated campaign to confuse people' over COVID test
node.alt: Composite image of Greg Hunt (L) and Steven Miles (R)
node.description: The Queensland and federal governments point fingers at each other for delays in clarifying the funding arrangement for COVID-19Â tests required by anyone travelling in and out of the state from next month.
node.content:
["The Queensland and federal governments are blaming each other for delays in clarifying the funding arrangement for COVID-19\u00a0tests required by anyone travelling in and out of the state from next month.", "A negative PCR result will be required within a 72-hour period before\u00a0travelling to Queensland,\u00a0but after days of argument\u00a0between\u00a0state and federal authorities\u00a0it was clarified that the $150 price tag will not\u00a0be the responsibility of holiday-makers.", "Federal Health Minister Greg Hunt said on Tuesday afternoon said the 50-50\u00a0arrangement had\u00a0been in place for some time.", "\"Testing has been proceeding without incident for the last 18 months,\" he said.", "\"This includes testing required to support entry into another state or territory.\"", "Queensland's Deputy Premier Steven Miles this morning welcomed Mr Hunt's\u00a0clarification, saying \"we\u00a0just wish it had a bit sooner\".", "\"Just yesterday, Greg Hunt was saying we should drop the requirement for a PCR test, I had to comment on that yesterday morning, and by yesterday afternoon, he was clarifying that PCR test would be free for people travelling to Queensland and we welcome that confirmation.\"", "Queensland has recorded no new cases of COVID-19 in the community and it has been 14 days since the last case in a recent Gold Coast cluster, which Deputy Chief Health Officer Lynne McKinlay said brought that outbreak to a close.", "One case was detected in hotel quarantine in a traveller from PNG and the state now has three active cases \u2014 the lowest number of\u00a0any time this year.", "Speaking on Channel Nine this morning, Mr Hunt said he was pleased Queensland Premier Annastacia Palaszczuk was \"back in the tent\" on joint funding of PCR tests.", "Mr Hunt said the Queensland government \"wavered\"\u00a0on the funding agreement over the past 24 to 48 hours.", "\"For some reason \u2014 whether it was inadvertent or otherwise\u00a0\u2014 they suggested they might be changing that.\u00a0In the end, they\u2019ve agreed to continue to do exactly what has been occurring over the last 18 months.", "\"They\u2019re back in the tent and I'm pleased about that, because the only people who would have lost are families and those that wanted to visit friends and sick relatives.\"", "Mr Miles was asked why the state government had not offered clarity on who was paying for the tests earlier.\u00a0", "He said it was the media reporting that tests would cost travellers and the state government had been responding to questions on that basis.", "\"We never floated that, there was never an announcement from the state government that it would cost people,\" he said.", "\"We were asked whether people would need the test and we were presented with the argument that in some cases that would cost people money, and we said they would still require that test.\"", "
'A\u00a0Christmas gift for consumers'
", "Tourism operators have expressed their joy and relief at the clarification.", "", "
Tourism operators say the clarity is a \"Christmas gift for consumers\".(ABC News: Tara Cassidy)
", "Queensland Tourism Industry Council chief executive Daniel Gschwind said it was\u00a0a massive relief for the sector.", "\"I think families will be a lot happier to spend the same amount on a tourism experience and bring themselves a bit of joy, and the industry, instead of spending it on a PCR test,\" he said.", "", "
Going overseas? Here's what you need to know
", "Tourism operators reported a spike in bookings when Premier Annastacia Palaszczuk announced Queensland's roadmap.", "The wave of enthusiasm was overshadowed by a\u00a0realisation a family of four would need to pay\u00a0$600 on COVID-19 tests just to enter the state.", "Mr Gschwind said the cost of testing would've been another blow to an already struggling industry.", "\"The state government and the private sector spent millions of dollars\u00a0trying to attract people now that the borders are open again through marketing, and this would've been a shot in the foot for sure,\" he said.", "He said it was a relief to operators who had been fielding calls from concerned travellers.", "\"We're enormously relieved that these bookings will hopefully hold, and people will arrive in a good mood without having their wallets raided before they get here.\"", "While it was a long road to get to this point, Mr Gschwind said, \"it's a very joyful moment and a Christmas gift for consumers.\""]
